name: nytimes
text:
Hiring in the U.S. increased in June for the second straight month. 

But the jobs data was collected before coronavirus cases began to spike in several states.

Here’s what we know. https://t.co/6uPL522O20

name: nytimes
text:
The unemployment rate fell to 11.1% in June as 4.8 million people headed back to work.

But more than twice as many people were involuntarily in part-time jobs in June than in February, and the economy remains in a deep hole. https://t.co/2iXbd0UZj3 https://t.co/FaM4FJO7t7

name: nytimes
text:
The June numbers were collected mid-month and don’t account for the 1.4 million new state unemployment claims and 800,000 federal claims filed last week.

Economists fear new layoffs as states order some businesses to close again. https://t.co/2iXbd0UZj3 https://t.co/l7ePhXTVfG

name: nytimes
text:
More Black men were unemployed in June than in May — the only group of people that didn’t see improvement. 

A major concern is that service and low-wage workers, who are disproportionately people of color, will have more trouble getting back to work. https://t.co/2iXbd0UZj3 https://t.co/99hehjNA46

name: nytimes
text: Industries that were battered early in the pandemic — like restaurants and retail — saw the most job gains last month. Construction, manufacturing and professional services brought back workers as well. https://t.co/2iXbd0UZj3 https://t.co/ZZSWZDIldM

name: nytimes
text:
Though reopening may bring back jobs, the rebound won’t last if new activity brings more virus cases. “The virus drives the economics,” said Betsey Stevenson, an economic adviser to President Obama. 

Read more about the latest numbers. https://t.co/2iXbd0UZj3
